I probably should have done that from the start. Anyways after searching ar=
ound for a while for different variables to output and where, while trying =
to figure out the program just be simple trial and error running, I found o=
ut that the constants were read off of a saved file instead of straight out=
 of the GUI. I was trying to avoid saving over the default, so I hadn't sav=
ed any of my bizarre parameter changes before. I tried running some weird s=
tuff after writing to file, and it behaved as expected.

Long story short: =
user error. 

Thank you for your time.
Sincerely,
=A0 John Lisco

--- On Tu=
e, 9/29/09, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:

From: Ken <kstanley@...=
xas.edu>
Subject: [neat] Re: jNeat Confusion
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date:=
 Tuesday, September 29, 2009, 11:58 AM






=A0




    
                 =
 John, that sounds like a potential bug.  Can you find in the code where th=
e mutate_add_link and mutate_add_node methods are called?  You should be ab=
le to see the condition it is checking to decide whether to call them.  Tha=
t will tell you if the variable in question is the only factor in the condi=
tion.  If it is, then it is possible that the variable itself is not being =
reset properly through the GUI, which you can check by outputting the varia=
ble when the condition is checked.  



ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups. com=
, John Lisco <jlisc0@...> wrote:

l pointed me this way. Anyways, what happened was I was messing

 constants in the GUI, and running the test runs to see the

> kind of netw=
orks became champions and such. So I set mutate_add_link

> and mutate_add_=
node both to 0.0, and watched the champion view. To my

> surprise, I got s=
ome fairly complex networks.

> I believe it was logical to expect the netw=
orks to all be identical

> structure to the initial structure. Is somethin=
g wrong with the

> testing, or did I miss something?

> Thank you for your=
 time.

                <p>John, that sounds like a potential bug.  Can you find in=
 the code where the mutate_add_link and mutate_add_node methods are called?=
  You should be able to see the condition it is checking to decide whether =
to call them.  That will tell you if the variable in question is the only f=
actor in the condition.  If it is, then it is possible that the variable it=
self is not being reset properly through the GUI, which you can check by ou=
tputting the variable when the condition is checked.  <br>
<br>
ken<br>
